evidence: The data are actually collected in the k-space.
Each coordinate, k_x and k_y, corresponds to a Fourier component of the image.
MRI does not record the image directly. Instead, it records data in k-space, which is really the Fourier space, and then uses the inverse transform to bring everything back into an image we can see.

concepts.term: after finishing one line, you step the phase-encoding gradient to a new value, moving up or down in the k y direction, and then record another frequency-encoded line

evidence: MRI does not record the image directly. Instead, it records data in k-space, which is really the Fourier space
